How elite schools like Stanford became fixated on the AI apocalypseNitasha Tiku7/5/2023

Student-led groups focused on AI Safety have popped up at Stanford University and other schools, backed by billionaires fixated on the AI apocalypse

TechnologyRead

In-depth DC, Virginia, Maryland news coverage including traffic, weather, crime, education, restaurant reviews and more.","sku":"https://subscribe.washingtonpost.com","image":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/resizer/2CjPNwqvXHPS_2RpuRTKY-p3eVo=/1484x0/www.washingtonpost.com/pb/resources/img/twp-social-share.png","brand":{"@type":"brand","name":"The Washington Post"},"offers":{"@type":"offer","url":"https://subscribe.washingtonpost.com/acquisition?promo=o26"}},"publisher":{"@id":"washingtonpost.com","@type":"NewsMediaOrganization","name":"The Washington Post","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-stat/img/wplogo_344x60_blk.png","width":{"@type":"Distance","name":"344 px"},"height":{"@type":"Distance","name":"60 px"}}},"isAccessibleForFree":false,"hasPart":{"@type":"WebPageElement","cssSelector":".article-body","value":"Paul Edwards, a Stanford University fellow who spent decades studying nuclear war and climate change, considers himself “an apocalypse guy.” So Edwards jumped at the chance in 2018 to help develop a freshman class on preventing human extinction. Working with epidemiologist Steve Luby, a professor of medicine and infectious disease, the pair focused on three familiar threats to the species — global pandemics, extreme climate change and nuclear winter — along with a fourth, newer menace: advanced artificial intelligence. On that last front, Edwards thought young people would be worried about immediate threats, such as AI-powered surveillance, misinformation or autonomous weapons that target and kill without human intervention — problems he calls “ultraserious.” But he soon discovered that some students were more focused on a purely hypothetical risk: that AI could become as smart as humans and destroy mankind.  Science fiction has long contemplated rogue AI, from HAL 9000 to  Skynet. But in recent years, Silicon Valley has become enthralled by a distinct vision of how super-intelligence might go awry, derived from thought experiments at the fringes of tech culture. In these scenarios, AI isn’t necessarily sentient. Instead, it becomes fixated on a goal — even a mundane one, such as making paper clips — and triggers human extinction to optimize its task.   To prevent this theoretical but cataclysmic outcome, mission-driven labs such as DeepMind, OpenAI and Anthropic are racing to build a good kind of AI programmed not to lie, deceive or kill us. Meanwhile, donors such as Tesla CEO Elon Musk, disgraced FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried, Skype founder Jaan Tallinn and ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin — as well as institutions such as Open Philanthropy, a charitable organization started by billionaire Facebook co-founder Dustin Moskovitz — have worked to push doomsayers from the tech industry’s margins into the mainstream. More recently, wealthy tech philanthropists have begun recruiting an army of elite college students to prioritize the fight against rogue AI over other threats. Open Philanthropy alone has funneled nearly half a billion dollars into developing a pipeline of talent to fight rogue AI, building a scaffolding of think tanks, YouTube channels, prize competitions, grants, research funding and scholarships — as well as a new fellowship that can pay student leaders as much as $80,000 a year, plus tens of thousands of dollars in expenses.  At Stanford, Open Philanthropy awarded Luby and Edwards more than $1.5 million in grants to launch the Stanford Existential Risk Initiative, which supports student research in the growing field known as “AI safety” or “AI alignment.” It also hosts an annual conference and sponsors a student group, one of dozens of AI safety clubs that Open Philanthropy has helped support in the past year at universities around the country. Critics call the AI safety movement unscientific. They say its claims about existential risk can sound closer to a religion than research. And while the sci-fi narrative resonates with public fears about runaway AI, critics say it obsesses over one kind of catastrophe to the exclusion of many others.  “The conversation is just hijacked,” said Timnit Gebru, former co-lead of Ethical AI at Google. Gebru and other AI ethicists say the movement has drawn attention away from existing harms — such as racist algorithms that determine who gets a mortgage or AI models that scrape artists’ work without compensation — and drown out calls for remedies. Other skeptics, including venture capitalist Marc Andreessen, are AI boosters who say that hyping such fears will impede the technology’s progress. Open Philanthropy spokesperson Mike Levine said harms such as algorithmic racism deserve a robust response. But he said those problems stem from the same root issue: AI systems not behaving as their programmers intended. The theoretical risks “were not garnering sufficient attention from others — in part because these issues were perceived as speculative,” Levine said in a statement. He compared the nonprofit’s AI focus to its work on pandemics, which also was regarded as theoretical until the coronavirus emerged.  The foundation began prioritizing existential risks around AI in 2016, according to a blog post by co-chief executive Holden Karnofsky, a former hedge funder whose wife and brother-in-law co-founded the AI start-up Anthropic and previously worked at OpenAI. At the time, Karnofsky wrote, there was little status or money to be gained by focusing on risks. So the nonprofit set out to build a pipeline of young people who would filter into top companies and agitate for change from the inside. Colleges have been key to this growth strategy, serving as both a pathway to prestige and a recruiting ground for idealistic talent. Over the past year and a half, AI safety groups have cropped up on about 20 campuses in the United States and Europe — including Harvard, Georgia Tech, MIT, Columbia and New York University — many led by students financed by Open Philanthropy’s new university fellowship.  The clubs train students in machine learning and help them find jobs in AI start-ups or one of the many nonprofit groups dedicated to AI safety. Many of these newly minted student leaders view rogue AI as an urgent and neglected threat, potentially rivaling climate change in its ability to end human life. Many see advanced AI as the Manhattan Project of their generation. Among them is Gabriel Mukobi, 23, who graduated from Stanford in June and is transitioning into a master’s program for computer science. Mukobi helped organize a campus AI safety group last summer and dreams of making Stanford a hub for AI safety work. Despite the school’s ties to Silicon Valley, Mukobi said it lags behind nearby UC Berkeley, where younger faculty members research AI alignment, the term for embedding human ethics into AI systems. “This just seems like a really, really important thing,” Mukobi said, “and I want to make it happen.”  An alternate universe When Mukobi first heard the theory that AI could eradicate humanity, he found it hard to believe. At the time, Mukobi was a sophomore on a gap year during the pandemic. Back then, he was concerned about animal welfare, promoting meat alternatives and ending animal agriculture. But then Mukobi joined Stanford’s club for effective altruism, known as EA, a philosophical movement that advocates doing maximum good by calculating the expected value of charitable acts, such as protecting the future from runaway AI. By 2022, AI capabilities were advancing all around him — wild developments that made those warnings seem prescient. Last summer, he announced the Stanford AI Alignment group (SAIA) in a blog post with a diagram of a tree representing his plan. He’d recruit a broad group of students (the soil) and “funnel” the most promising candidates (the roots) up through the pipeline (the trunk). To guard against the “reputational hazards” of toiling in a field some consider sketchy, Mukobi wrote, “we’ll prioritize students and avoid targeted outreach to unaligned AI professors.” Among the reputational hazards of the AI safety movement is its association with an array of controversial figures and ideas, like EA, which is also known for recruiting ambitious young people on elite college campuses. EA’s drive toward maximizing good initially meant persuading top graduates in rich countries to go into high-paying jobs, rather than public service, and donate their wealth to causes such as buying mosquito nets to save lives in malaria-racked countries in Africa.   But from the start EA was intertwined with tech subcultures interested in futurism and rationalist thought. Over time, global poverty slid down the cause list, while rogue AI climbed toward the top. Extreme practitioners began to promote an idea called “longtermism,” prioritizing the lives of people potentially millions of years in the future, who might be a digitized version of human beings, over present-day suffering. In the past year, EA has been beset by scandal, including the fall of Bankman-Fried, one of its largest donors. Another key figure, Oxford philosopher Nick Bostrom, whose 2014 bestseller “Superintelligence” is essential reading in EA circles, met public uproar when a decades-old diatribe about IQ surfaced in January. “Black are more stupid than whites,” Bostrom wrote, calling the statement “logically correct,” then using the n-word in a hypothetical example of how his words could be misinterpreted as racist. Bostrom apologized for the slur but little else.  After reading Bostrom’s diatribe, SAIA stopped giving away copies of “Superintelligence.” Mukobi, who identifies as biracial, called the message “sus” but saw it as Bostrom’s failure — not the movement’s. Mukobi did not mention EA or longtermism when he sent an email to Stanford’s student listservs in September touting his group’s student-led seminar on AI safety, which counted for course credit. Programming future AI systems to share human values could mean “an amazing world free from diseases, poverty, and suffering,” while failure could unleash “human extinction or our permanent disempowerment,” Mukobi wrote, offering free boba tea to anyone who attended the 30-minute intro. Students who join the AI safety community sometimes get more than free boba. Just as EA conferences once meant traveling the world and having one-on-one meetings with wealthy, influential donors, Open Philanthropy’s new university fellowship offers a hefty direct deposit: undergraduate leaders receive as much as $80,000 a year, plus $14,500 for health insurance, and up to $100,000 a year to cover group expenses.   The movement has successfully influenced AI culture through social structures built around swapping ideas, said Shazeda Ahmed, a postdoctoral research associate at Princeton University’s Center for Information Technology Policy. Student leaders have access to a glut of resources from donor-sponsored organizations, including an “AI Safety Fundamentals” curriculum developed by an OpenAI employee. Interested students join reading groups where they get free copies of books like “The Precipice” and may spend hours reading the latest alignment papers, posting career advice on the Effective Altruism forum, or adjusting their P(doom), a subjective estimate of the probability that advanced AI will end badly. The grants, travel, leadership roles for inexperienced graduates and sponsored co-working spaces build a close-knit community. Edwards discovered that shared online forums function like a form of peer review, with authors changing their original text in response to the comments. “It’s really readable writing, which is great,” Edwards said, but it bypasses the precision of vetting ideas through experts. “There’s a kind of alternate universe where the academic world is being cut out.” Edwards’s first book was on the military origins of AI, and he recently served on the United Nations’ chief climate panel, leaving him too rooted in real-world science and politics to entertain the kind of dorm-room musings accepted at face value in the forums. Could AI take over all the computers necessary to end humanity? “Not happening,” Edwards said. “Too many humans in the loop. And there will be for 20 or 30 years.”  The ‘EA Kool-Aid’ Since the launch of ChatGPT in November, discussion of AI safety has exploded at a dizzying pace. Corporate labs that view advanced artificial intelligence as inevitable and want the social benefits to outweigh the risks are increasingly touting AI safety as the antidote to the worst-feared outcomes. At Stanford, Mukobi has tried to capitalize on the sudden interest. After Yoshua Bengio, one of the “godfathers” of deep learning, signed an open letter in March urging the AI industry to hit pause, Mukobi sent another email to Stanford student listservs warning that AI safety was being eclipsed by rapid advances in the field. “Everyone” is “starting to notice some of the consequences,” he wrote, linking each word to a recent op-ed, tweet, Substack post, article or YouTube video warning about the perils of unaligned AI. By then, SAIA had already begun its second set of student discussions on introductory and intermediate AI alignment, which 100 students have completed so far. “You don’t get safety by default, you have to build it in — and nobody even knows how to do this yet,” he wrote. In conversation, Mukobi is patient and more measured than in his email solicitations, cracking the occasional self-deprecating joke. When told that some consider the movement cultish, he said he understood the concerns. (Some EA literature also embraces nonbelievers. “You’re right to be skeptical of these claims,” says the homepage for Global Challenges Project, which hosts three-day expenses-paid workshops for students to explore existential risk reduction.)  Mukobi feels energized about the growing consensus that these risks are worth exploring. He heard students talking about AI safety in the halls of Gates, the computer science building, in May after Geoffrey Hinton, another “godfather” of AI, quit Google to warn about AI. By the end of the year, Mukobi thinks the subject could be a dinner-table topic, just like climate change or the war in Ukraine. Luby, Edwards’s teaching partner for the class on human extinction, also seems to find these arguments persuasive. He had already rearranged the order of his AI lesson plans to help students see the imminent risks from AI. No one needs to “drink the EA Kool-Aid” to have genuine concerns, he said. Edwards, on the other hand, still sees things such as climate change as a bigger threat than rogue AI. But ChatGPT and the rapid release of AI models has convinced him that there should be room to think about AI safety. Interest in the topic is also growing among Stanford faculty members, Edwards said. He noted that a new postdoctoral fellow will lead a class on alignment next semester in Stanford’s storied computer science department. The course will not be taught by students or outside experts. Instead, he said, it “will be a regular Stanford class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Paul Edwards, a Stanford University<b> </b>fellow who spent decades studying nuclear war and climate change, considers himself “an apocalypse guy.” So Edwards jumped at the chance in 2018 to help develop a freshman class on preventing human extinction.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Working with epidemiologist Steve Luby, a professor of medicine and infectious disease, the pair focused on three familiar threats to the species — global pandemics, extreme climate change and nuclear winter — along with a fourth, newer menace: advanced artificial intelligence.</p></div></div><div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">On that last front, Edwards thought young people would be worried about immediate threats, such as AI-powered surveillance, misinformation or autonomous weapons that target and kill without human intervention — problems he calls “ultraserious.” But he soon discovered that some students were more focused on a purely hypothetical risk: that AI could become as smart as humans and destroy mankind.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Science fiction has long contemplated rogue AI, from HAL 9000 to  Skynet. But in recent years, Silicon Valley has become enthralled by a distinct vision of how super-intelligence might go awry, derived from thought experiments at the fringes of tech culture. In these scenarios, AI isn’t necessarily sentient. Instead, it becomes fixated on a goal — even a mundane one, such as making paper clips — and triggers human extinction to optimize its task.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-image" class="hide-for-print"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body grid-tablet-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-image" class="hide-for-print"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">To prevent this theoretical but cataclysmic outcome, mission-driven labs such as DeepMind, OpenAI and Anthropic are racing to build a good kind of AI programmed not to lie, deceive or kill us. Meanwhile, donors such as Tesla CEO Elon Musk, disgraced<b> </b>FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried, Skype founder Jaan Tallinn and ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin — as well as institutions such as Open Philanthropy, a charitable organization started by billionaire Facebook co-founder Dustin Moskovitz —<b> </b>have worked to push doomsayers from the tech industry’s margins into the mainstream.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">More recently, wealthy tech philanthropists have begun recruiting an army of elite college students to prioritize the fight against rogue AI over other threats. <a href="https://www.openphilanthropy.org/" target=_blank>Open Philanthropy</a> alone has funneled nearly half a billion dollars into developing a pipeline of talent to fight rogue AI, building a scaffolding of think tanks, YouTube channels, prize competitions, grants, research funding and scholarships — as well as a new fellowship that can pay student leaders as much as $80,000 a year, plus tens of thousands of dollars in expenses.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="wpds-c-VkPmP hide-for-print"><div></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">At Stanford, Open Philanthropy awarded Luby and Edwards more than $1.5 million in grants to launch the <a href="https://seri.stanford.edu/" target=_blank>Stanford Existential Risk Initiative</a>, which supports student research in the growing field known as “AI safety” or “AI alignment.” It also hosts an annual conference and sponsors a student group, one of dozens of AI safety clubs that Open Philanthropy has helped support in the past year at universities around the country.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Critics call the AI safety movement unscientific. They say its claims about existential risk can sound closer to a religion than research. And while the sci-fi narrative resonates with public fears about runaway AI, critics say it<b> </b>obsesses over one kind of catastrophe to the exclusion of many others.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-image" class="hide-for-print"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“The conversation is just hijacked,” said Timnit Gebru, former co-lead of Ethical AI at Google.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Gebru and other AI ethicists say the movement has drawn attention away from existing harms — such as racist algorithms that determine who gets a mortgage or AI models that scrape artists’ work without compensation — and drown out calls for remedies. Other skeptics, including venture capitalist Marc Andreessen, are AI boosters who say that hyping such fears will impede the technology’s progress.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Open Philanthropy spokesperson Mike Levine said harms such as algorithmic racism deserve a robust response. But he said those problems stem from the same root issue: AI systems not behaving as their programmers intended. The theoretical risks “were not garnering sufficient attention from others — in part because these issues were perceived as speculative,” Levine said in a statement. He compared the nonprofit’s AI focus to its work on pandemics, which also was regarded as theoretical until the coronavirus emerged.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The foundation began prioritizing existential risks around AI in 2016, according to a <a href="https://www.openphilanthropy.org/research/potential-risks-from-advanced-artificial-intelligence-the-philanthropic-opportunity/" target=_blank>blog post</a> by co-chief executive Holden Karnofsky, a former hedge funder whose wife and brother-in-law co-founded the AI start-up Anthropic and previously worked at OpenAI. At the time, Karnofsky wrote, there was little status or money to be gained by focusing on risks. So the nonprofit set out to build a pipeline of young people who would filter into top companies and agitate for change from the inside.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Colleges have been key to this growth strategy, serving as both a pathway to prestige and a recruiting ground for idealistic talent. Over the past year and a half, AI safety groups have cropped up on about 20 campuses in the United States and Europe — including Harvard, Georgia Tech, MIT, Columbia and New York University — many led by students financed by Open Philanthropy’s new <a href="https://www.openphilanthropy.org/grants/university-organizer-fellowship/" target=_blank>university fellowship</a>.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-image" class="hide-for-print"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The clubs train students in machine learning and help them find jobs in AI start-ups or one of the many nonprofit groups dedicated to AI safety.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Many of these newly minted student leaders view rogue AI as an urgent and neglected threat, potentially rivaling climate change in its ability to end human life. Many see advanced AI as the Manhattan Project of their generation.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Among them is Gabriel Mukobi, 23, who graduated from Stanford in June and is transitioning into a master’s program for computer science. Mukobi helped organize a campus AI safety group last summer and dreams of making Stanford a hub for AI safety work. Despite the school’s ties to Silicon Valley, Mukobi said it lags behind nearby UC Berkeley, where younger faculty members research AI alignment, the term for embedding human ethics into AI systems.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“This just seems like a really, really important thing,” Mukobi said, “and I want to make it happen.”</p></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-md" id="U3AL7GSF2VD7RNIXMIPQYXJSUU"><div>An alternate universe</div></h3></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">When Mukobi first heard the theory that AI could eradicate humanity, he found it hard to believe. At the time, Mukobi was a sophomore on a gap year during the pandemic. Back then, he was concerned about animal welfare, promoting meat alternatives and ending animal agriculture.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">But then Mukobi joined Stanford’s club for effective altruism, known as EA, a philosophical movement that advocates doing maximum good by calculating the expected value of charitable acts, such as protecting the future from runaway AI. By 2022, AI capabilities were advancing all around him — wild developments that made those warnings seem prescient.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Last summer, he announced the <a href="https://stanfordaialignment.org/" target=_blank>Stanford AI Alignment</a> group (SAIA) in a blog post with a diagram of a tree representing his plan. He’d recruit a broad group of students (the soil) and “funnel” the most promising candidates (the roots) up through the pipeline (the trunk). To guard against the “reputational hazards” of toiling in a field some consider sketchy, Mukobi wrote, “we’ll prioritize students and avoid targeted outreach to unaligned AI professors.”</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Among the reputational hazards of the AI safety movement is its association with an array of controversial figures and ideas, like EA, which is also known for recruiting ambitious young people on elite college campuses.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">EA’s drive toward maximizing good initially meant persuading top graduates in rich countries to go into high-paying jobs, rather than public service, and donate their wealth to causes such as buying mosquito nets to save lives in malaria-racked countries in Africa.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-image-group"><div></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">But from the start EA was intertwined with tech subcultures interested in futurism and rationalist thought. Over time, global poverty slid down the cause list, while rogue AI climbed toward the top. Extreme practitioners began to promote an idea called “longtermism,” prioritizing the lives of people potentially millions of years in the future, who might be a digitized version of human beings, over present-day suffering.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">In the past year, EA has been beset by scandal, including the fall of Bankman-Fried, one of its largest donors. Another key figure, Oxford philosopher Nick Bostrom, whose 2014 bestseller “Superintelligence” is essential reading in EA circles, met public uproar when a decades-old diatribe about IQ surfaced in January.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“Black are more stupid than whites,” Bostrom wrote, calling the statement “logically correct,” then using the n-word in a hypothetical example of how his words could be misinterpreted as racist. Bostrom <a href="https://nickbostrom.com/oldemail.pdf" target=_blank>apologized</a> for the slur but little else.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">After reading Bostrom’s diatribe, SAIA stopped giving away copies of “Superintelligence.” Mukobi, who identifies as biracial, called the message “sus” but saw it as Bostrom’s failure — not the movement’s.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Mukobi did not mention EA or longtermism when he sent an email to Stanford’s student listservs in September touting his group’s student-led seminar on AI safety, which counted for course credit. Programming future AI systems to share human values could mean “an amazing world free from diseases, poverty, and suffering,” while failure could unleash “human extinction or our permanent disempowerment,” Mukobi wrote, offering free boba tea to anyone who attended the 30-minute intro.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Students who join the AI safety community sometimes get more than free boba. Just as EA conferences once meant traveling the world and having one-on-one meetings with wealthy, influential donors, Open Philanthropy’s new university fellowship offers a hefty direct deposit: undergraduate leaders receive as much as $80,000 a year, plus $14,500 for health insurance, and up to $100,000 a year to cover group expenses.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-image" class="hide-for-print"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body grid-tablet-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-image" class="hide-for-print"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The movement has successfully influenced AI culture through social structures built around swapping ideas, said Shazeda Ahmed, a postdoctoral research associate at Princeton University’s Center for Information Technology Policy. Student leaders have access to a glut of resources from donor-sponsored organizations, including an “AI Safety Fundamentals” curriculum developed by an OpenAI employee.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Interested students join reading groups where they get free copies of books like “The Precipice” and may spend hours reading the latest alignment papers, posting career advice on the Effective Altruism forum, or adjusting their P(doom), a subjective estimate of the probability that advanced AI will end badly. The grants, travel, leadership roles for inexperienced graduates and sponsored co-working spaces build a close-knit community.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Edwards discovered that shared online forums function like a form of peer review, with authors changing their original text in response to the comments.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“It’s really readable writing, which is great,” Edwards said, but it bypasses the precision<b> </b>of vetting ideas through experts. “There’s a kind of alternate universe where the academic world is being cut out.”</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Edwards’s first book was on the military origins of AI, and he recently served on the United Nations’ chief climate panel, leaving him too rooted in real-world science and politics to entertain the kind of dorm-room musings accepted at face value in the forums.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Could AI take over all the computers necessary to end humanity? “Not happening,” Edwards said. “Too many humans in the loop. And there will be for 20 or 30 years.”</p></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-md" id="AKSTVVCU3ZGIZEUGJQAKODKINM"><div>The ‘EA Kool-Aid’</div></h3></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Since the launch of ChatGPT in November, discussion of AI safety has exploded at a dizzying pace. Corporate labs that view advanced artificial intelligence as inevitable and want the social benefits to outweigh the risks are increasingly touting AI safety as the antidote to the worst-feared outcomes.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">At Stanford, Mukobi has tried to capitalize on the sudden interest.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">After Yoshua Bengio, one of the “godfathers” of deep learning, signed an open letter in March urging the AI industry to<b> </b>hit pause, Mukobi sent another email to Stanford student listservs warning<b> </b>that AI safety was being eclipsed by rapid advances in the field. “Everyone” is “starting to notice some of the consequences,” he wrote, linking each word to a recent op-ed, tweet, Substack post, article or YouTube video warning about the perils of unaligned AI.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">By then, SAIA had already begun its second set of student discussions on introductory and intermediate AI alignment, which 100 students have completed so far.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“You don’t get safety by default, you have to build it in — and nobody even knows how to do this yet,” he wrote.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">In conversation, Mukobi is patient and more measured than in his email solicitations, cracking the occasional self-deprecating joke. When told that some consider the movement cultish, he said he understood the concerns. (Some EA literature also embraces nonbelievers. “You’re right to be skeptical of these claims,” says the homepage for Global Challenges Project, which hosts three-day expenses-paid workshops for students to explore existential risk reduction.)</p></div><div class="article-body grid-full-bleed" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-image" class="hide-for-print"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Mukobi feels energized about the growing consensus that these risks are worth exploring.<b> </b>He heard students talking about AI safety in the halls of Gates, the computer science building, in May after Geoffrey Hinton, another “godfather” of AI, quit Google to warn about AI. By the end of the year, Mukobi thinks the subject could be a dinner-table topic, just like climate change or the war in Ukraine.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Luby, Edwards’s teaching partner for the class on human extinction, also seems to find these arguments persuasive. He had already rearranged the order of his AI lesson plans to help students see the imminent risks from AI. No one needs to “drink the EA Kool-Aid” to have genuine concerns, he said.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Edwards, on the other hand, still sees things such as climate change as a bigger threat than rogue AI. But ChatGPT and the rapid release of AI models has convinced him that there should be room to think about AI safety.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Interest in the topic is also growing among Stanford faculty members, Edwards said. He noted that a new postdoctoral fellow will lead a class on alignment next semester in Stanford’s storied computer science department.</p></div><div class="article-body grid-center grid-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The course will not be taught by students or outside experts. Instead, he said, it “will be a regular Stanford class.”</p></div><div class="flex mt-md grid-center grid-body"><div class="mb-lg-mod" data-qa="comments-btn-div"><button aria-label="Scroll to the a professor of medicine and infectious disease, the pair focused on three familiar threats to the species — global pandemics, extreme climate change and nuclear winter — along with a fourth, newer menace: advanced artificial intelligence.","type":"text"},{"_id":"4W5BRKPHFJAOFPOC5IIR2KOKVI","additional_properties":{},"content":"On that last front, Edwards thought young people would be worried about immediate threats, such as AI-powered surveillance, misinformation or autonomous weapons that target and kill without human intervention — problems he calls “ultraserious.” But he soon discovered that some students were more focused on a purely hypothetical risk: that AI could become as smart as humans and destroy mankind.","type":"text"},{"_id":"G6VPY3UB5FGBZLIQHGQSK3GNOU","additional_properties":{},"subtype":"inline_ad","type":"divider"},{"_id":"XDP2J4S635GYXLBAVUSSDOATII","additional_properties":{},"content":"Science fiction has long contemplated rogue AI, from HAL 9000 to  Skynet. But in recent years, Silicon Valley has become enthralled by a distinct vision of how super-intelligence might go awry, derived from thought experiments at the fringes of tech culture. In these scenarios, AI isn’t necessarily sentient. Instead, it becomes fixated on a goal — even a mundane one, such as making paper clips — and triggers human extinction to optimize its task.","type":"text"},{"_id":"T7SMWPRZNHAPELHSREPN4IM3IM","additional_properties":{"keywords":["ai","ai alignment","ai safety","ea","stanford","artificial general intelligence","artificial intelligence","college students","computer science","computer systems","effective altruism","university"],"media_size":"large"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kori Suzuki"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"Hoover Tower at Stanford University. (Kori Suzuki for The Washington Post)","height":2661,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/T7SMWPRZNHAPELHSREPN4IM3IM.jpg","width":4000},{"_id":"U7EBWL6U5ZKG6YWVNKA3ZJDHWU","additional_properties":{"media_size":"medium"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Davide Orsini"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"Paul Edwards is a Stanford University fellow who spent decades studying nuclear war and climate change. (Davide Orsini)","height":923,"subtype":"Image","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/U7EBWL6U5ZKG6YWVNKA3ZJDHWU.jpg","width":1280},{"_id":"P33DTXHI7RC47MJR5A3BVKVCO4","additional_properties":{},"content":"To prevent this theoretical but cataclysmic outcome, mission-driven labs such as DeepMind, OpenAI and Anthropic are racing to build a good kind of AI programmed not to lie, deceive or kill us. Meanwhile, donors such as Tesla CEO Elon Musk, disgraced\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003eFTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried, Skype founder Jaan Tallinn and ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin — as well as institutions such as Open Philanthropy, a charitable organization started by billionaire Facebook co-founder Dustin Moskovitz —\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003ehave worked to push doomsayers from the tech industry’s margins into the mainstream.","type":"text"},{"_id":"BHTVM2QQKFDHDGQKLZI3ZCXTX4","additional_properties":{},"content":"More recently, wealthy tech philanthropists have begun recruiting an army of elite college students to prioritize the fight against rogue AI over other threats. \u003ca href=\"https://www.openphilanthropy.org/\" target=_blank\u003eOpen Philanthropy\u003c/a\u003e alone has funneled nearly half a billion dollars into developing a pipeline of talent to fight rogue AI, building a scaffolding of think tanks, YouTube channels, prize competitions, grants, research funding and scholarships — as well as a new fellowship that can pay student leaders as much as $80,000 a year, plus tens of thousands of dollars in expenses.","type":"text"},{"_id":"VVJLVJKYEFBJXIG4KMJMRIZVZ4","additional_properties":{},"embed":{"config":{"title":"More on AI","subtype":"collection"},"url":"https://prism.wpit.nile.works/content/v4/collections?content_alias=ai","id":"ai"},"subtype":"magnet","type":"custom_embed"},{"_id":"P33DTXHI7RC47MJR5A3BVKVCO4","additional_properties":{},"content":"At Stanford, Open Philanthropy awarded Luby and Edwards more than $1.5 million in grants to launch the \u003ca href=\"https://seri.stanford.edu/\" target=_blank\u003eStanford Existential Risk Initiative\u003c/a\u003e, which supports student research in the growing field known as “AI safety” or “AI alignment.” It also hosts an annual conference and sponsors a student group, one of dozens of AI safety clubs that Open Philanthropy has helped support in the past year at universities around the country.","type":"text"},{"_id":"IC2E2VE2WRBXRB4RWMQ7E3ALGI","additional_properties":{},"content":"Critics call the AI safety movement unscientific. They say its claims about existential risk can sound closer to a religion than research. And while the sci-fi narrative resonates with public fears about runaway AI, critics say it\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003eobsesses over one kind of catastrophe to the exclusion of many others.","type":"text"},{"_id":"MSWA5TT6VYUGKFDZO65WV5RYYE","additional_properties":{"keywords":["ai","ai alignment","ai safety","ea","stanford","artificial general intelligence","artificial intelligence","college students","computer science","computer systems","effective altruism","university"],"media_size":"large"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kori Suzuki"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"Encina Hall houses the Stanford Existential Risks Initiative. (Kori Suzuki/For The Washington Post)","height":2661,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/MSWA5TT6VYUGKFDZO65WV5RYYE.jpg","width":4000},{"_id":"JFPNDC7DT5FHPJBTIABJFRZQ4Y","additional_properties":{},"content":"“The conversation is just hijacked,” said Timnit Gebru, former co-lead of Ethical AI at Google.","type":"text"},{"_id":"UHYU5P6WCJA5HFVYZ4FZQDUUY4","additional_properties":{},"content":"Gebru and other AI ethicists say the movement has drawn attention away from existing harms — such as racist algorithms that determine who gets a mortgage or AI models that scrape artists’ work without compensation — and drown out calls for remedies. Other skeptics, including venture capitalist Marc Andreessen, are AI boosters who say that hyping such fears will impede the technology’s progress.","type":"text"},{"_id":"OJUAEBBJ2ZA3LD7P37JQVWDGG4","additional_properties":{},"content":"Open Philanthropy spokesperson Mike Levine said harms such as algorithmic racism deserve a robust response. But he said those problems stem from the same root issue: AI systems not behaving as their programmers intended. The theoretical risks “were not garnering sufficient attention from others — in part because these issues were perceived as speculative,” Levine said in a statement. He compared the nonprofit’s AI focus to its work on pandemics, which also was regarded as theoretical until the coronavirus emerged.","type":"text"},{"_id":"L6AIBRE67FCQJAHDIUO3JYQCQ4","additional_properties":{},"subtype":"inline_ad","type":"divider"},{"_id":"NFUNMWA7LZHCXAVCIY3GGHG5HE","additional_properties":{},"content":"The foundation began prioritizing existential risks around AI in 2016, according to a \u003ca href=\"https://www.openphilanthropy.org/research/potential-risks-from-advanced-artificial-intelligence-the-philanthropic-opportunity/\" target=_blank\u003eblog post\u003c/a\u003e by co-chief executive Holden Karnofsky, a former hedge funder whose wife and brother-in-law co-founded the AI start-up Anthropic and previously worked at OpenAI. At the time, Karnofsky wrote, there was little status or money to be gained by focusing on risks. So the nonprofit set out to build a pipeline of young people who would filter into top companies and agitate for change from the inside.","type":"text"},{"_id":"HCBE255LZJH5VJ675Y44EWC5GY","additional_properties":{},"content":"Colleges have been key to this growth strategy, serving as both a pathway to prestige and a recruiting ground for idealistic talent. Over the past year and a half, AI safety groups have cropped up on about 20 campuses in the United States and Europe — including Harvard, Georgia Tech, MIT, Columbia and New York University — many led by students financed by Open Philanthropy’s new \u003ca href=\"https://www.openphilanthropy.org/grants/university-organizer-fellowship/\" target=_blank\u003euniversity fellowship\u003c/a\u003e.","type":"text"},{"_id":"LVB6RRRYODUBR3ETVRR7L7IMOU","additional_properties":{"keywords":["ai","ai alignment","ai safety","ea","stanford","artificial general intelligence","artificial intelligence","college students","computer science","computer systems","effective altruism","university"],"media_size":"large"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kori Suzuki"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"People on the Stanford campus. (Kori Suzuki/For The Washington Post)","height":2661,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/LVB6RRRYODUBR3ETVRR7L7IMOU.jpg","width":4000},{"_id":"XJIGZNTKOBAARIIGZINWQ742KA","additional_properties":{},"content":"The clubs train students in machine learning and help them find jobs in AI start-ups or one of the many nonprofit groups dedicated to AI safety.","type":"text"},{"_id":"UNIH536CYBF3BAEUPFOPRGIRNQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Many of these newly minted student leaders view rogue AI as an urgent and neglected threat, potentially rivaling climate change in its ability to end human life. Many see advanced AI as the Manhattan Project of their generation.","type":"text"},{"_id":"24GRBSHLVFGMJF322ZKMBOAMSQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Among them is Gabriel Mukobi, 23, who graduated from Stanford in June and is transitioning into a master’s program for computer science. Mukobi helped organize a campus AI safety group last summer and dreams of making Stanford a hub for AI safety work. Despite the school’s ties to Silicon Valley, Mukobi said it lags behind nearby UC Berkeley, where younger faculty members research AI alignment, the term for embedding human ethics into AI systems.","type":"text"},{"_id":"7L7DFUZBNBGRLEBMB5DLWWX3EY","additional_properties":{},"content":"“This just seems like a really, really important thing,” Mukobi said, “and I want to make it happen.”","type":"text"},{"_id":"SPCGPOOMXZEQTLLY73QJKZZ3JQ","additional_properties":{},"subtype":"inline_ad","type":"divider"},{"_id":"U3AL7GSF2VD7RNIXMIPQYXJSUU","additional_properties":{},"content":"\u003cb\u003eAn alternate universe\u003c/b\u003e","level":2,"type":"header"},{"_id":"447YU4JUVRBK5BSQVXIN4XVBVY","additional_properties":{},"content":"When Mukobi first heard the theory that AI could eradicate humanity, he found it hard to believe. At the time, Mukobi was a sophomore on a gap year during the pandemic. Back then, he was concerned about animal welfare, promoting meat alternatives and ending animal agriculture.","type":"text"},{"_id":"2AOUJK6W6ZFWHER3IDWLSYN374","additional_properties":{},"content":"But then Mukobi joined Stanford’s club for effective altruism, known as EA, a philosophical movement that advocates doing maximum good by calculating the expected value of charitable acts, such as protecting the future from runaway AI. By 2022, AI capabilities were advancing all around him — wild developments that made those warnings seem prescient.","type":"text"},{"_id":"GHQRXB2HDJCRDGR5UMHMC5FEJU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Last summer, he announced the \u003ca href=\"https://stanfordaialignment.org/\" target=_blank\u003eStanford AI Alignment\u003c/a\u003e group (SAIA) in a blog post with a diagram of a tree representing his plan. He’d recruit a broad group of students (the soil) and “funnel” the most promising candidates (the roots) up through the pipeline (the trunk). To guard against the “reputational hazards” of toiling in a field some consider sketchy, Mukobi wrote, “we’ll prioritize students and avoid targeted outreach to unaligned AI professors.”","type":"text"},{"_id":"BCHPA5KXMNBH3LTNEV3NZ7IRKI","additional_properties":{},"content":"Among the reputational hazards of the AI safety movement is its association with an array of controversial figures and ideas, like EA, which is also known for recruiting ambitious young people on elite college campuses.","type":"text"},{"_id":"4AQZTCSBI5D77PELFFVVXCUPNA","additional_properties":{},"content":"EA’s drive toward maximizing good initially meant persuading top graduates in rich countries to go into high-paying jobs, rather than public service, and donate their wealth to causes such as buying mosquito nets to save lives in malaria-racked countries in Africa.","type":"text"},{"_id":"CPEUQJ5V3I5WRWKVA66Z4WWIXE","additional_properties":{"keywords":["ai","ai alignment","ai safety","ea","stanford","artificial general intelligence","artificial intelligence","college students","computer science","computer systems","effective altruism","university"],"media_size":"small"},"alignment":"left","credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kori Suzuki"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"A bicyclist moves along Jane Stanford Way. (Kori Suzuki/For The Washington Post)","height":4000,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/CPEUQJ5V3I5WRWKVA66Z4WWIXE.jpg","width":2661},{"_id":"6TMBLGSLGXJMJG5B5JAZAUXUCE","additional_properties":{"keywords":["ai","ai alignment","ai safety","ea","stanford","artificial general intelligence","artificial intelligence","college students","computer science","computer systems","effective altruism","university"],"media_size":"small"},"alignment":"right","credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kori Suzuki"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"Memorial Court at Stanford. (Kori Suzuki/For The Washington Post)","height":3983,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/6TMBLGSLGXJMJG5B5JAZAUXUCE.jpg","width":2655},{"_id":"H67O6D6MYJE4FPYFXA3OFO4OME","additional_properties":{},"content":"But from the start EA was intertwined with tech subcultures interested in futurism and rationalist thought. Over time, global poverty slid down the cause list, while rogue AI climbed toward the top. Extreme practitioners began to promote an idea called “longtermism,” prioritizing the lives of people potentially millions of years in the future, who might be a digitized version of human beings, over present-day suffering.","type":"text"},{"_id":"VGBFB7UFDVCC3MRKQ3RDVG4OBI","additional_properties":{},"content":"In the past year, EA has been beset by scandal, including the fall of Bankman-Fried, one of its largest donors. Another key figure, Oxford philosopher Nick Bostrom, whose 2014 bestseller “Superintelligence” is essential reading in EA circles, met public uproar when a decades-old diatribe about IQ surfaced in January.","type":"text"},{"_id":"5ESJ5PBCJZGSBDRTULIQLO5HYE","additional_properties":{},"content":"“Black are more stupid than whites,” Bostrom wrote, calling the statement “logically correct,” then using the n-word in a hypothetical example of how his words could be misinterpreted as racist. Bostrom \u003ca href=\"https://nickbostrom.com/oldemail.pdf\" target=_blank\u003eapologized\u003c/a\u003e for the slur but little else.","type":"text"},{"_id":"KJVEDI7PLJH77E4K5Y54VTWGAU","additional_properties":{},"subtype":"inline_ad","type":"divider"},{"_id":"EMVTHLJE65EK3BUG2FY4WJCACI","additional_properties":{},"content":"After reading Bostrom’s diatribe, SAIA stopped giving away copies of “Superintelligence.” Mukobi, who identifies as biracial, called the message “sus” but saw it as Bostrom’s failure — not the movement’s.","type":"text"},{"_id":"H75RHINSCRAJRIA66R3BUZCKF4","additional_properties":{},"content":"Mukobi did not mention EA or longtermism when he sent an email to Stanford’s student listservs in September touting his group’s student-led seminar on AI safety, which counted for course credit. Programming future AI systems to share human values could mean “an amazing world free from diseases, poverty, and suffering,” while failure could unleash “human extinction or our permanent disempowerment,” Mukobi wrote, offering free boba tea to anyone who attended the 30-minute intro.","type":"text"},{"_id":"CSHNL6F23FCQNJPSML4S33IGSU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Students who join the AI safety community sometimes get more than free boba. Just as EA conferences once meant traveling the world and having one-on-one meetings with wealthy, influential donors, Open Philanthropy’s new university fellowship offers a hefty direct deposit: undergraduate leaders receive as much as $80,000 a year, plus $14,500 for health insurance, and up to $100,000 a year to cover group expenses.","type":"text"},{"_id":"EWVGXLN4LBXNPNHANTCKYTK34E","additional_properties":{"keywords":["ai","ai alignment","ai safety","ea","stanford","artificial general intelligence","artificial intelligence","college students","computer science","computer systems","effective altruism","university"],"media_size":"large"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kori Suzuki"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"A student works in the hallway at Stanford’s Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence inside the William Gates Computer Science building. (Kori Suzuki/For The Washington Post)","height":2661,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/EWVGXLN4LBXNPNHANTCKYTK34E.jpg","width":4000},{"_id":"OYMISGZYUVJADRDO4CS37EJJEQ","additional_properties":{"keywords":["ai","ai alignment","ai safety","ea","stanford","artificial general intelligence","artificial intelligence","college students","computer science","computer systems","effective altruism","university"],"media_size":"medium"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kori Suzuki"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"The Gates building at Stanford. (Kori Suzuki/For The Washington Post)","height":2661,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/OYMISGZYUVJADRDO4CS37EJJEQ.jpg","width":4000},{"_id":"Q7EPNGYQANE4LLOG2DLY6UKBSU","additional_properties":{},"content":"The movement has successfully influenced AI culture through social structures built around swapping ideas, said Shazeda Ahmed, a postdoctoral research associate at Princeton University’s Center for Information Technology Policy. Student leaders have access to a glut of resources from donor-sponsored organizations, including an “AI Safety Fundamentals” curriculum developed by an OpenAI employee.","type":"text"},{"_id":"M53WQ3HBFNDV3LDAYR7GVHG7XU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Interested students join reading groups where they get free copies of books like “The Precipice” and may spend hours reading the latest alignment papers, posting career advice on the Effective Altruism forum, or adjusting their P(doom), a subjective estimate of the probability that advanced AI will end badly. The grants, travel, leadership roles for inexperienced graduates and sponsored co-working spaces build a close-knit community.","type":"text"},{"_id":"27ERODYQAFDHLFAIAHWAOU3EII","additional_properties":{},"content":"Edwards discovered that shared online forums function like a form of peer review, with authors changing their original text in response to the comments.","type":"text"},{"_id":"FIZSKPXB5BB2JNCVPKHZJDTZA4","additional_properties":{},"content":"“It’s really readable writing, which is great,” Edwards said, but it bypasses the precision\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003eof vetting ideas through experts. “There’s a kind of alternate universe where the academic world is being cut out.”","type":"text"},{"_id":"CZHD57MMK5GWLP6ISNP3BVBCNA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Edwards’s first book was on the military origins of AI, and he recently served on the United Nations’ chief climate panel, leaving him too rooted in real-world science and politics to entertain the kind of dorm-room musings accepted at face value in the forums.","type":"text"},{"_id":"RIIYD7AQE5CDVASRGWVOISKTOU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Could AI take over all the computers necessary to end humanity? “Not happening,” Edwards said. “Too many humans in the loop. And there will be for 20 or 30 years.”","type":"text"},{"_id":"G7LKL7MPWFFKVPSFTNGU2WFNMU","additional_properties":{},"subtype":"inline_ad","type":"divider"},{"_id":"AKSTVVCU3ZGIZEUGJQAKODKINM","additional_properties":{},"content":"\u003cb\u003eThe ‘EA Kool-Aid’\u003c/b\u003e","level":2,"type":"header"},{"_id":"5VDEM6DEU5AOBGOU2D72QPHVCQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Since the launch of ChatGPT in November, discussion of AI safety has exploded at a dizzying pace. Corporate labs that view advanced artificial intelligence as inevitable and want the social benefits to outweigh the risks are increasingly touting AI safety as the antidote to the worst-feared outcomes.","type":"text"},{"_id":"G3XSEZJOOJBAFFJ4WD3NBLPBJI","additional_properties":{},"content":"At Stanford, Mukobi has tried to capitalize on the sudden interest.","type":"text"},{"_id":"NEKDU3NOY5HVNGGSZF44SIUWZA","additional_properties":{},"content":"After Yoshua Bengio, one of the “godfathers” of deep learning, signed an open letter in March urging the AI industry to\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003ehit pause, Mukobi sent another email to Stanford student listservs warning\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003ethat AI safety was being eclipsed by rapid advances in the field. “Everyone” is “starting to notice some of the consequences,” he wrote, linking each word to a recent op-ed, tweet, Substack post, article or YouTube video warning about the perils of unaligned AI.","type":"text"},{"_id":"3IEQR2WXK5GQ5MVF72BDAJGI44","additional_properties":{},"content":"By then, SAIA had already begun its second set of student discussions on introductory and intermediate AI alignment, which 100 students have completed so far.","type":"text"},{"_id":"Y2CBA6YHYJHQBOFTC7JSMQMOMI","additional_properties":{},"content":"“You don’t get safety by default, you have to build it in — and nobody even knows how to do this yet,” he wrote.","type":"text"},{"_id":"VI7YA7JG5RFB3KXVS76PXAS5VY","additional_properties":{},"content":"In conversation, Mukobi is patient and more measured than in his email solicitations, cracking the occasional self-deprecating joke. When told that some consider the movement cultish, he said he understood the concerns. (Some EA literature also embraces nonbelievers. “You’re right to be skeptical of these claims,” says the homepage for Global Challenges Project, which hosts three-day expenses-paid workshops for students to explore existential risk reduction.)","type":"text"},{"_id":"X6MTVMSRVNH5CJAUKYCGELXKJQ","additional_properties":{"keywords":["ai","ai alignment","ai safety","ea","stanford","artificial general intelligence","artificial intelligence","college students","computer science","computer systems","effective altruism","university"],"media_size":"large"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kori Suzuki"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"Stanford graduate Gabriel Mukobi. (Kori Suzuki/For The Washington Post)","height":2670,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/X6MTVMSRVNH5CJAUKYCGELXKJQ.jpg","width":4000},{"_id":"EHRGS6GG55AJNKSWPCS3RRM5OU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Mukobi feels energized about the growing consensus that these risks are worth exploring.\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003eHe heard students talking about AI safety in the halls of Gates, the computer science building, in May after Geoffrey Hinton, another “godfather” of AI, quit Google to warn about AI. By the end of the year, Mukobi thinks the subject could be a dinner-table topic, just like climate change or the war in Ukraine.","type":"text"},{"_id":"LGQSMQ7JVJBMZPFYE5LBWBHTUU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Luby, Edwards’s teaching partner for the class on human extinction, also seems to find these arguments persuasive. He had already rearranged the order of his AI lesson plans to help students see the imminent risks from AI. No one needs to “drink the EA Kool-Aid” to have genuine concerns, he said.","type":"text"},{"_id":"4PC6EF6NJVE33MTJFGKFAQZN2Y","additional_properties":{},"content":"Edwards, on the other hand, still sees things such as climate change as a bigger threat than rogue AI. But ChatGPT and the rapid release of AI models has convinced him that there should be room to think about AI safety.","type":"text"},{"_id":"3FK33PL7TBATHIHRIKK2VTBCK4","additional_properties":{},"content":"Interest in the topic is also growing among Stanford faculty members, Edwards said. He noted that a new postdoctoral fellow will lead a class on alignment next semester in Stanford’s storied computer science department.","type":"text"},{"_id":"BL2JO7BFZ5G2HAVT3RWYYUPKRU","additional_properties":{},"content":"The course will not be taught by students or outside experts. Instead, he said, it “will be a regular Stanford class.”","type":"text"}],"content_restrictions":{"content_code":"default"},"credits":{"by":[{"_id":"tikun","additional_properties":{"original":{"_id":"tikun","affiliations":"","awards":[],"bio":"Nitasha Tiku is The Washington Post's tech culture reporter based in San Francisco.\n","bio_page":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/people/nitasha-tiku/","books":[],"byline":"Nitasha Tiku","contributor":false,"custom_washpost_desk_name_1":"Business","custom_washpost_desk_name_2":"Business - Technology Policy","education":[{"name":"Columbia University, BA in English"},{"name":"New York University, MA in Journalism"}],"email":"nitasha.tiku@washpost.com","employeeID":"000270715","expertise":"Tech culture reporter based in San Francisco","firstName":"Nitasha","fuzzy_match":false,"image":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/arc-authors/washpost/9384df9c-5c90-4aef-b9b1-24bbc62ed0ad.jpg","isWorkdayLoad":true,"jobProfile":"Staff Writer","lastName":"Tiku","last_updated_date":"2023-07-07T09:42:17.750Z","location":"San Francisco","longBio":"Nitasha Tiku is The Washington Post's tech culture reporter based in San Francisco.\n\nBefore joining The Post in 2019, Tiku had a decade of experience helping readers understand how Silicon Valley thinks and operates.
